Award.AwardTitle: INSPIRE: Assessing feasible regions of configuration spaces for macromolecular crystals

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This INSPIRE project is jointly funded by Algorithmic Foundations in CISE/CCF, Analysis in MPS/DMS, and the NSF Office of Integrative Activities.

Knowledge of the 3-dimensional structure of protein molecules supports scientific understanding of how proteins perform their functions within cells. Structures of over 100,000 proteins in the Protein Data Bank have been determined by macromolecular x-ray crystallography: measuring the diffraction of x-ray beams from crystal composed of many symmetrically arranged copies of one or more protein molecules gives partial information (the amplitudes of the Fourier transform) that must be filled in (solving the "phase problem," often by molecular replacement -- taking phases from related molecules) to complete the 3d structure. Molecular replacement works quite well for simple single-domain proteins, but breaks down for multi-domain proteins and large complexes; one needs to explore the possible combinations of domains and their diffraction patterns as replacement candidates.

This cross-disciplinary project brings together experts in robotics and in pure mathematics to address the ''phase problem'' of macromolecular x-ray crystallography. The mathematical and computational framework developed in this project will enable many more protein structures to be solved in a less laborious way than can be done now. The project also introduces Baltimore City high school students to mathematics and molecular biophysics through unique visualization activities.

The essence of combining domains is geometric. The team can use articulated multi-rigid-body models from the field of robotics to combine rigid portions of structures, from domains with similar sequences. The relative rigid-body motions between the domains become the unknown degrees of freedom in these articulated models. Crystal packing constraints will rule out the majority of possible configurations for these domains, and reduce the otherwise high-dimensional nature of the search space. The project will develop new algebro-geometric and computational methods for rapidly discarding the large collision regions in configuration space, so that searches will focus on the remaining small-volume feasible regions in this high-dimensional search space. Computer code will be prepared integrating the resulting methods into existing molecular crystallography software packages.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The field of structural biology is concerned with determining the shape of proteins and other large molecules of life, with the goal of understanding how these impact the function of organisms. A key method in structural biology is x-ray crystallography, which has been responsible for determining the shape of the vast majority of the approximately 170,000 macromolecular structures obtained to date. In this method, large molecules are coaxed into forming crystals which are analyzed with x-ray beams. 

While powerful, x-ray crystallography is known to suffer from the ``phase problem.'' This is a mathematical problem which stipulates that the experimental data must be augmented in some way in order to solve for structures.

Two versions of x-ray crystallography that address this phase problem have been known for decades: 1) isomorphous replacement, in which heavy metal atoms are experimentally introduced into proteins in order to generate additional x-ray data; 2) the method of molecular replacement, in which information from previously solved protein shapes is used to augment x-ray data. 

This project presents a new version of the molecular replacement method for phasing in macromolecular crystallography based on feasible geometric packing. By developing new algebro-geometric and computational methods for rapidly discarding the large infeasible collision regions in the configuration space, these search methods focus on the remaining small-volume feasible regions in this high-dimensional search space. The promise of the methods developed in this project is that the effectiveness and speed of molecular replacement can be enhanced, thereby making computational phasing even more attractive, and reducing the cost and time required to obtain additional experimental data.

The core innovation in this work centers around previously unknown properties of crystal symmetry and a mathematical construct called the Minkowski sum. In particular, it is shown that the regions in a crystal where proteins can be placed must be outside of cylinders with cross sections that are slices of Minkowsi sums. Moreover, if for a candidate rotation of the protein, these cylinders cover all of the possible locations for positioning the center of the protein, then that rotation can be labeled as infeasible without needing to do any additional calculations. This observation restricts the size of the search space in molecular replacement, thereby making such searches more efficient.

Consequently, a large part of the effort in this project is devoted to efficiently computing Minkowski sums and slices thereof. Closed-form expressions for Minkowski sums of ellipsoids and other convex bodies are derived, which can be used to encapsulate models of protein molecules. This fundamental mathematical development has benefits to other fields where Minkowski sums are used, such as in robot path planning, computational geometry, and in computer-aided design.
